user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
```c
int metal_generic_dev_dma_map(struct metal_bus *bus,
			     struct metal_device *device,
			     uint32_t dir,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_in,
			     int nents_in,
			     struct metal_sg *sg_out)
{
	int i;
	(void)bus;
	(void)device;

	if (sg_out != sg_in)
		memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
	for (i = 0; i < nents_in; i++) {
		if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_W) {
			metal_cache_flush(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
		}
		metal_cache_invalidate(sg_out[i].virt, sg_out[i].len);
	}

	return nents_in;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_generic_dev_dma_map:
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_W 2
...
struct metal_sg {
	void *virt; /**< CPU virtual address */
	struct metal_io_region *io; /**< IO region */
	int len; /**< length */
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (sg_out != sg_in)
	memcpy(sg_out, sg_in, nents_in*(sizeof(struct metal_sg)));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the conditional memcpy is controlled by the runtime comparison (sg_out != sg_in) of caller-supplied pointers; both true and false outcomes are possible, so the code is reachable.
